Award.AwardTitle: High Throughput Tip-Enhanced Near Field Microscopy using Radially Polarized Fiber Modes

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Tip-enhanced near-field microscopy using optical fiber vortices

Non-technical description: Optical microscopy is arguably one of the most successful techniques for non-invasive examination of the microscopic world ever created. In the last decade nanoscience, phenomena at length scales orders of magnitude smaller than the microscale, has played an increasingly larger role in the development of widespread technology such as nanoscale semiconductor devices, nanoparticle based therapies in medicine, and sensors that can measure minute forces and signals from biological as well as inanimate physical systems. Likewise, nanotechnology has also furthered our understanding of fundamental scientific phenomena at the nanoscale, such as the electronic structure of two-dimensional materials that promise to usher in the next generation of high-speed wearable electronic devices, images of intrinsic vibrational modes capable of sub-cellular classification and local presence of important proteins in biophysical systems. Probing, and in particular, optical probing at the nanoscale is thus of paramount importance to help lead the next revolution in science and technology much like the optical microscope did in the microscopic world. Our proposed optical fiber vortex light source will provide two to three orders of magnitude signal enhancement and background reduction in devices that can optically resolve nanoscale phenomena.

Technical description: The goal of this proposed program is to develop a tip-enhanced near-field microscopy system that retains all the advantages of current scattering type near-field scanning optical microscopes, including the ability to probe the amplitude and phase response of materials in the nanometer scale using well-established elastic or inelastic scattering techniques, but with an increased throughput by several orders of magnitude (simulations suggest the possibility of 75% efficiencies, as opposed to 0.1-0.2% in current implementations). This will reduce background problems that have limited the application of current implementations of tip-enhanced microscopy systems. The primary intellectual significance of achieving program goals will be the realization of a nanoscale microscopy system that can probe signals orders of magnitude weaker than currently possible, aided by the dramatic reductions in background that an optical fiber-based nanoscale tip would enable. In the proposed effort we will use fiber tapering, electrochemical etching techniques, and precision metal deposition techniques to adiabatically convert the stable radially polarized optical modes in the fiber into plasmonic modes at the fiber tip, as required for tip-enhanced microscopy. The adiabatic mode transformation, as opposed to external illumination as is currently employed, will be the key differentiator between current tip-enhanced microscopy systems and the proposed device, as this is expected to yield the two-to-three orders of magnitude increase in signal throughput and corresponding decrease in background.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall aim of this project was the development of optical fiber based devices that can efficiently, and without distortions, transmit exotic beam shapes of light that carry orbital angular momentum (OAM). Such beams, unlike conventional beams, travel in a helical path, i.e. they twist as they propagate, and share several physical analogies with spinning tops and tornadoes. These peculiar properties make them highly useful for applications ranging from classical internet capacity scaling and developing more secure quantum networks, to new ways to image in the nanoscale, which could allow discerning the cellular and sub-cellular dynamics of neuronal activity of the brain. Creating these beams in optical fibers has, however, been fraught with instabilities not unlike how atmospheric changes cause images to be distorted on a hot day. Hence, the central goal of this project was to develop a new class of optical fibers that can avoid these distortions, and success in these goals would automatically enable fiber-based versions of the aforementioned applications. This is significant because an optical fiber means of delivering and processing these beams allows for remote delivery, for example with endoscopes that can deliver the desired beams deep inside a living body, or by enabling new modalities of light-based communications, either to increase the capacity of data centers or for making quantum networks more secure.

A wide variety of optical fibers that can stably support, deliver and help manipulate OAM beams were developed over the course of this program. Interestingly, the course of these investigations revealed new physics for light propagation. Three notable examples are: (1) the discovery of a new regime of light-guidance that has enabled scaling the information carrying capacity by over a factor 25 compared to the conventional, commercially deployed fiber; (2) an inherent chirality effect that has enabled developing ultra-high resolution single-shot spectrometers; and (3) a way to suppress Raman noise in optical fibers - this noise has been one of the key bottlenecks to using optical fibers to directly generate quantum entangled photons. Besides these unexpected outcomes, significant progress was made on the expected outcomes of the project too. Noteworthy developments in this regard were the realization of an optical fiber that could potentially yield nano-scale imaging using principles of plasmonic light confinement or the principles of stimulated emission depletion microscopy, and the development of all-fiber devices to generate OAM modes, on demand, for various applications. These achievements have laid the foundations for future work where an optical fiber-based OAM beam generator would be readily available by various applications groups, and collaborations with other universities have already resulted in fibers developed in this program being used for a variety of microscopy experiments.

The fundamental as well as applied nature of the outcomes resulted, over the course of the program, in 16 journal publications, 26 conference presentations and 2 patents (one granted and one pending).

The broader impacts of this program have been twofold: (1) developing a robust platform for the robust generation and propagation of light carrying OAM, for a variety of applications that this fundamental field has spawned. Hence, specifically, developing fiber-based devices that would enable transitioning this promising technology; (2) broadening participation of students and postdoctoral scientists, including women and underrepresented minorities, in science and engineering, enabled by project guidelines and multiple outreach programs at BU.
